list_available_metrics.description: Lists all available metrics for forecasting, organized by category: social_engagement (Twitter, wiki pageviews), financial (salaries, valuations, endorsements), attendance (game attendance, crowd metrics). Use this to discover what can be forecasted.
list_available_metrics.returns: Dictionary mapping categories to available metric names. Categories include: social_engagement, financial, attendance, other

get_metric_info.description: Provides statistical summary of a specific metric: mean, median, standard deviation, min/max values, sample size, and missing data percentage. Use before forecasting to understand the metric's characteristics.

parameters.metric_name: string - Column name of the metric to examine

get_metric_info.returns: Dictionary with metric statistics: mean, median, std_dev, min, max, sample_size, missing_pct

auto_forecast.description: Automatically generates predictions for a metric by selecting optimal features using machine learning. The tool analyzes correlations and chooses the best predictive variables. Simplest forecasting method - requires only dataset name and target metric.

parameters.target_metric: string - Name of the metric to predict
parameters.current_context: dict (optional) - Current values for predictive features if available

auto_forecast.returns: StatisticalForecast with predicted_value, confidence_score, trend_direction, percent_change, prediction_interval_lower, prediction_interval_upper, volatility, sample_size, model_accuracy

forecast_metric.description: Generates predictions using manually specified feature columns. Provides control over which variables influence the forecast. Use when you know which features should drive predictions or when auto_forecast isn't sufficient.

parameters.feature_columns: list of strings - Column names to use as predictive features
parameters.current_values: dict (optional) - Current feature values for generating new predictions

forecast_metric.returns: StatisticalForecast with predicted_value, confidence_score, trend_direction, percent_change, prediction intervals, volatility, sample_size, model_accuracy

analyze_trend.description: Performs time-series analysis on a metric: calculates moving averages, trend coefficients, acceleration (rate of change in trend), detects seasonality patterns, and identifies anomalies. Does not make predictions - only analyzes historical patterns.

parameters.metric: string - Metric column name to analyze
parameters.window_size: int (optional, default=5) - Number of points for moving average calculation

analyze_trend.returns: TrendAnalysis with historical_values, moving_average, trend_coefficient, acceleration, seasonality_detected (boolean), anomaly_score

calculate_correlations.description: Computes correlation matrix for multiple variables and identifies statistically significant relationships. Shows correlation strength, p-values, and relationship types (weak, moderate, strong, very_strong). Useful for understanding which metrics influence each other.

parameters.variables: list of strings - Variable names to analyze for correlations

calculate_correlations.returns: List of CorrelationInsight objects with variable_x, variable_y, correlation_strength (-1 to 1), statistical_significance (0 to 1), relationship_type

get_dataset_summary.description: Provides overview of all loaded datasets: row counts, column lists (separated by numeric vs categorical), and missing data percentages. Use to understand available data structure before forecasting.
get_dataset_summary.returns: Dictionary mapping dataset names to their metadata: rows, columns, numeric_columns, categorical_columns, missing_data_pct
